Comments_List: Learn more about immune system development can know more experimental models people use. Practice to write proposal

I learned more of how to navigate the literature of a new field and become more critical of opinions and data in papers that I would have previously accepted as fact with less critical evaluation. This is crucial for my development as a researcher and this class is unique for offering that training.
This class discussed the principles of immune system development through weekly readings covering topics ranging from hematopoiesis to lymphocyte function.
Learning more about the field of lymphocyte development and also unanswered questions after discussing readings
It's good chance to learn more about B cell development and discuss with students and professors.

Sometimes it was daunting to have so many papers assigned (suggested) every week and left little time or energy to explore related work. On the other hand I did get better at reducing the time I spent to get the main idea of a paper from over an hour to less than an hour.

This course could be improved by assigning reviews rather than primary literature. Allowing students to pick primary literature may prevent classes from becoming journal clubs, as not all students would have read the same primary papers. It may also help the presentations be broader to improve engagement in discussions by having open-ended questions.
Yes. It's a good course to learn more about immune system and can get a lot feedback from students and professors.
Yes I would. I learned very useful skills in research evaluation and trying to formulate unasked questions that are revealed from holes in existing work.
Yes, this course allowed for self-directed learning of topics and discussions were interesting and thought-provoking.
